channel.title: Implementing netty to replace mina
channel.description: Is there a particular book that best outlines java networking? I want to utilize netty in place of Mina but do not have a clue how to do so. What resource was the most helpful in getting up to speed?

item.title: Implementing netty to replace mina
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

I’m sure nobody would use it. Not only because it’s a very basic server, but also because it’s quite hard to set everything up, so that you can compile and run it, unless you know what you’re doing. It’s not just one project, so you need to compile them in the correct order. And I use Ant, not Maven, which probably makes it harder. Last of all, I’m not really satisfied with that server so far, but have no time to work on it either. I havn’t done anything on it in a few months.

Read full topic

I’d love to see this community doing anything productive.

-Nothing:

The major things are ran by the game engine thread. Events, clientupdating, player/npc movement. If you are using any of the public sources available.

*No, my server does not run on one thread.

Read full topic

item.title: Implementing netty to replace mina
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

SHA512 isn’t encryption bro. And as discussed elsewhere, it’s not particularly ideal for password storage (although it is superior to md5 and other earlier SHA implementations).
Ideally you should use a key derivation algorithm that takes a work factor argument (i.e., PBKDF2).

While netty is better than mina, I don’t know why this discussion is making such a fuss. It’s not a panacea.

Finally, having another language for scripting is less important now, in my opinion, due to java having lambda expressions.

Read full topic

item.title: Implementing netty to replace mina
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:21, topic:542711”][quote author=-Nothing link=topic=661586.msg4423017#msg4423017 date=1399349331]

Sure player count is low but that doesn’t mean we haven’t stress tested it. CPU usage has never gone over 2%. Object release your latest rsc source publicly so the community can move on.

The server runs on one thread which is why it can never access the full power of your CPU, so stop looking at your CPU usage, instead benchmark the delays.
[/quote]

No, the server does not run on one thread :P[/quote]
The major things are ran by the game engine thread. Events, clientupdating, player/npc movement. If you are using any of the public sources available.

item.title: Implementing netty to replace mina
item.dc:creator: @cleako cleako
item.description:
@cleako wrote:

Finally was able to play around with PRSC and see what makes it different from stock DarkQuest. It includes netty in place of mina, uses python for scripts instead of java, bsh, or scala, it has a connection throttle filter and automatic IP banning, utilizes SHA512 password encryption as well as a private salt for database security, and has a pretty startup within console for the LS and GS. Client has a built in hash checker for cache updates when not running localhost and added fonts for capcha. Active tile was removed. Everything else is content from what I see. Response time running localhost compared to stock DarkQuest is nearly identical. Start up time is considerably longer for the GS in PRSC with most diverted to the landscape and python scripts.

Read full topic

item.title: Implementing netty to replace mina
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

I would like for you to discuss the ActiveTile lookup ‘flaws’ and how it can be improved?

Upon every mob movement the entity is removed from the tile and added to another which will be quite a hog with thousands of npcs walking around the landscape every 600ms, meaning that every 600ms few thousand removals and additions to ActiveTiles happen. Then in order to fix the memory leaking, you need to have an event running cleaning it, because it’s design is flawed and entities are left behind after removal. Can you see why it’s inefficient?

Something just crosed my mind, Does anybody know why the TileValues and ActiveTiles are stored seperately in seperate arrays when they both represent tiles and the tile values could be saved in the ActiveTile class?

	public final ActiveTile[][] tiles = new ActiveTile[MAX_WIDTH][MAX_HEIGHT];

	private final TileValue[][] tileType = new TileValue[MAX_WIDTH][MAX_HEIGHT];

A great improvement would be to scrap the ActiveTiles, and use a region system as seen on many servers out today, this way the entities can be easily looked up and each time they move you don’t need to remove and add them on tiles, you would only need to change the entities sectors when needed. Saving memory and CPU.

Read full topic

Read full topic

item.title: Implementing netty to replace mina
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:8, topic:542711”]done *publicly

@Cleako The major part is the GameEngine and ClientUpdater. Fix those.[/quote]
You can’t really “fix” those, you need to rewrite the way it all works. Think what affects the latency between client request and server response and while you are at it think how it will work when under lots of stress. There are countless design flaws in RSCD such as single threaded game logic, shared incoming(And outgoing on some versions) packet list for all players, which will block others when one players packet is being handled, the “ActiveTile” approach for entity location verification/lookup.
I could go on but I think you all know this already.

Read full topic

item.title: Implementing netty to replace mina
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Justin Bieber:

just use mina… netty is terrible

Unjustified, incorrect, and you’re comparing apples to oranges.

They have entirely different purposes, I’d recommend doing some research before making such blatant statements that reflect your ignorance

Read full topic
